However, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for FbFTL DP does not depend on these factors. Furthermore, the final performance also depends on the robustness of each framework against noise. Therefore, we demonstrate the comparisons via experiments in the following subsection.

V-C Experimental Results

In our experiments, we utilize the dataset CIFAR-10 which has N=10ğ‘10N=10 types of labels, and is well-balanced (i.e., Py,true=Py,unisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¦truesubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¦uniP_{y,\text{true}}=P_{y,\text{uni}}). We generate shuffled batches according to the uniform sample distribution Py,unisubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¦uniP_{y,\text{uni}} and evaluate the total label privacy leakage in different scenarios in Fig. 11. The blue curve plots the initial uncertainty Hâ€‹(B|Py,uni)ğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¦uniH(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}}) for different values of Kğ¾K (where Kğ¾K is the number of samples from each client). Each of the other curves shows the uncertainty given shuffled data Hâ€‹(B|ğ’U=cU)ğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ’ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ˆH(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}) with fixed total amount of samples Uâ€‹Kğ‘ˆğ¾UK from all clients, and the number of clients Uğ‘ˆU is determined by each value of Kğ¾K accordingly. By DefinitionÂ 1 and DefinitionÂ 2, the total label privacy leakage given shuffled data is Ltl=Lsl+Lqlsuperscriptsubscriptğ¿ğ‘¡ğ‘™subscriptsuperscriptğ¿ğ‘™ğ‘ subscriptsuperscriptğ¿ğ‘™ğ‘L_{t}^{l}=L^{l}_{s}+L^{l}_{q} and is equal to the difference Hâ€‹(B|Py,uni)âˆ’Hâ€‹(B|ğ’U=cU)ğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¦uniğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ’ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ˆH(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})-H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}). We see that Hâ€‹(B|Py,uni)â‰ˆHâ€‹(B|ğ’U=cU)ğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¦uniğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ’ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ˆH(B\ |\ P_{y,\text{uni}})\approx H(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}) when Kğ¾K is small, and thus the label privacy is well preserved. However, for given value of the product Uâ€‹Kğ‘ˆğ¾UK, Hâ€‹(B|ğ’U=cU)ğ»conditionalğµsubscriptğ’ğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ˆH(B\ |\ \mathcal{C}_{U}=c_{U}) diminishes fast once a certain threshold of Kğ¾K is exceeded. Therefore, we note that the label privacy leakage becomes high when Kğ¾K is large. As addressed before, the label privacy applies in the same way to both FbFTL and gradient-based FedAvg frameworks, and hence a smaller Kğ¾K might be preferred in order to preserve the label privacy. However, current FL privacy analyses typically focus on DP that provides a relatively loose upper bound on the total local privacy. Within the DP setting, studies typically consider a small number of clients and assume that each client obtains hundreds of samples, if not thousands of, to achieve improved DP performance. However, as we have observed above, a setting with higher values of Kğ¾K can lead to higher label privacy loss (in addition to requiring more training epochs and achieving less validation accuracy). This leads to the important conclusion that the balance between different types of privacy leakage needs to be considered carefully.

To compare the DP performances of feature privacy leakage, we apply different noise levels Ïƒğœ\sigma on upload content gâ€‹(d)ğ‘”dg(\textbf{d}) of different frameworks to achieve the same level (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta) of privacy, and compare the validation accuracy at convergence with different Kğ¾K in Fig. 12. In our experiments, we implement the moments accountant via RÃ©nyi Divergence-based DP accountant to get a tighter bound. With fixed Î´=10âˆ’6ğ›¿superscript106\delta=10^{-6}, each plot shows the validation accuracy at convergence as a function of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon for given Kğ¾K. We note that higher Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon indicates weaker DP protection, lower noise level Ïƒğœ\sigma, and thus higher accuracy (closer to the original performance without noise). As shown in Fig. 11, label privacy is better preserved at K=4ğ¾4K=4, and we show the DP performance within the same setting in Fig. 12(a). While gradient-based FedAvg frameworks totally fail, FbFTL has good performance because it has much smaller data size |gâ€‹(d)|ğ‘”d|g(\textbf{d})| and is more robust against noise, as it receives constant data instead of varying perturbation in each training iteration and converges to a sub-optimal model. Such advantage of FbFTL remains until Kğ¾K increases to 100 as shown in Fig. 12(b), where FTL that updates the task-specific sub-model outperforms FbFTL at Ïµâ‰¥4italic-Ïµ4\epsilon\geq 4 as they have the same data size |gâ€‹(d)|ğ‘”d|g(\textbf{d})| while the noise level of FedAvg decreases as Kğ¾K increases. However, the label privacy completely leaks for Kâ‰¥16ğ¾16K\geq 16 as we have seen in Fig. 11. FedAvg for Kâ‰¥16ğ¾16K\geq 16 only prevails in protecting the subset of feature privacy that is not mitigated via shuffling. In Fig. 12(c), we show the comparison for even larger K=600ğ¾600K=600, where all types of FedAvg perform better than FbFTL.

Note that it is extremely difficult to analytically evaluate the volume of feature privacy leakage that can be mitigated via shuffling. Howeover, we can compare the performances of FbFTL and FedAvg for a given Kğ¾K via experimental results as done above. One key conclusion we have is the following. In terms of privacy preservation, FbFTL is preferred when Kğ¾K is small (i.e., each client obtains a small set of samples), and gradient-based FedAvg is preferred when Kğ¾K is large.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we have presented a novel communication-efficient federated transfer learning method. In this proposed feature-based federated transfer learning (FbFTL), the features and outputs are uploaded rather than the gradient updates. We have provided a thorough description of the system design and the learning algorithm, and compared its theoretical payload with that of federated learning and federated transfer learning. Our results demonstrate substantial reductions in both uplink and downlink payload when using FbFTL. Via experiments, we have further shown the effectiveness of the proposed FbFTL by showing that FbFTL reduces the uplink payload by up to five orders of magnitude compared to that of existing methods. Subsequently, we have demonstrated that FbFTL with small batch size has significantly less packet loss rate than gradient-based frameworks, and illustrated its robustness against data insufficiency and quantization. Finally, we have considered different types of privacy leakage, and analyzed mitigation approaches. Specifically, we have first analyzed label privacy leakage with both statistical knowledge and query (resulting in access to the label outputs). We have identified a condition under which label privacy vanishes. We have also addressed feature privacy and considered a DP mechanism for preserving this privacy. We have shown that with small Kğ¾K and shuffling that eliminates label privacy leakage, FbFTL also attains good differential feature privacy protection. These characterizations and results render FbFTL a communication-efficient, robust, and privacy-preserving novel federated transfer learning scheme.
